description: From Middle English during, durynge, durinde, durand, durende, present participle of duren (“to last”), equivalent to dure +‎ -ing. Compare Dutch gedurende (“during”). More at dure.

entries.meaning: For all of a given time interval.
examples: I lived with my parents during the 1970s.
The shop was one of the few able to stay open during the war.

entries.meaning: At any time or period within a given time interval.
examples: I lived with my parents at several points during the 1980s.
Many of the best examples were produced during the Restoration.
